column1: When will the yield curve for 2-year and 10-year US Treasury bonds next invert?
column5: ['Before 23 April 2022', 'Between 23 April 2022 and 20 May 2022', 'Between 21 May 2022 and 17 June 2022', 'Not before 18 June 2022']

column6: By today's close (01 April 2022), it'll certainly be in the data. Seriously, no joke.

This has happened. It was very brief so it doesn't show up on the FRED link provided in the description. https://www.zerohedge.com/markets/2s10s-inverts-stocks-sink-after-unemployment-rate-tumbles-earnings-jump
Today's datapoint is reported as 0.06 - inversion is likely to happen in the following two days depending on how the daily value is calculated.
leaving a little wiggle room just incase it doesn't technically satisfy the question, inverted at close

I agree with @steven_meyer - I think there is a fair chance noise will invert the curve for a couple of days pretty soon. If the yield curve for 2-year bonds becomes less steep in the following days, it would be good to reconsider.
The yield curve is flat. Given the downward presssure from short term interest rate hikes and inflation, the yield curve will inverte before April 23.

As of writing this forecast the 2-Year yield is sitting at ~2.383% and the 10-Year yield is sitting at ~2.388%. Practically flat. Noise alone should be reason enough to consider this a significant possibility at this point.

The slope of the yield curve is basically zero at the moment. There seems to be a selling panic among short term treasuries driving up yields; as they seek to switch investments to longer term treasuries with longer maturities and less IR risk sensitivity, they drive down yields in the longer terms. The question is whether the FRED data will come out negative today to resolve this question as of 29 Mar 2022.
Today, it is 0.08% from inverting. Clearly the prob for the curve to invert before April 23 has increased!
moving higher into bin 1 because variance may make this happen much sooner than the trend in general

The trend indicates it will be in the next month or so, which should hold true if the fed continues to indicate interest rates are increasing. Leaving a 50% chance opening to a major reversal stopping that from happening though - either the Fed indicating some major direction change or another stimulus bill getting traction.

The next FMOC meeting is early May. I do not think we will see inversion before the next rate hike, but there is always a chance. Aften FMOC, the short end rate will increase and the long end should decrease as activity is expected to dampen. However, the process may take some time which means it may happen after May 20

Bond markets move faster than expected discounting future economic situations. Discounting the next Fed move of +50 basis points for Fed funds and little change in employment stats will give the yield curve inversion momentum. The Russia/Ukrainian war and re projections of inflationary expectations are the wild cards in probabilities for 2/10 yield inversion. Watch for liquidity issues for 10 yr + treasury maturities which may delay an inversion. We all know the Fed is in rate raising motion, what we donâ€™t know is what the market wants or can discount for the unknown interim events.
